column1: Between 1 April 2022 and 30 September 2022, will lethal confrontations between the national military forces, militia, and/or law enforcement personnel (forces) of Armenia and Azerbaijan result in 100 or more fatalities?
column6: ['Foreign Policy', 'Security and Conflict', 'Non-US Politics']
Spokesperson for Foreign Minister of Armenia confirms 105 casualties as of this morning via Twitter (@ armspoxmfa)
99 killed today.
We have AP reporting 99 fatalities today plus a few that took place over the summer so this question has resolved as far as I can tell.
The most recent death toll I was able to find is 50+49. But I expect this toll to rise, as @orchidny notes.
https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/world/putin-seeks-to-calm-azerbaijan-and-armenia-after-49-killed-in-clashes/ar-AA11LlzF49 Armenians killed, unknown number of Azeris.
The Armenian PM said 49 have been killed from the Armenian side. Final casualties figure expected to be much higher. Shelling continues.
Surprising, nonetheless.
And they were almost doing so well. . . .

Numerous reports on Twitter tonight that heavy shelling and air strikes are continuing to take place on the Armenian-Azerbaijani border. A reported ceasefire, negotiated by Russia, appears to have collapsed, multiple military bases in the region are said to have taken severe damage/casualties but no confirmation so far.
Heavy fighting being reported tonight.

Looks like things are escalating dramatically. If artillery is involved, fatalities could quickly add up to 100 before the 30th. Twitter.com/NeilPHauer/status/1569433181119737857?t=feYDd8N_kMRNjZhypFDQQw&s=19
EU mediated peace talks will be fast tracked.
Passage of time. Also the last flare-up seems to be successfully tamped down.
Passage of time. Also this:
Up a bit on recent news, though 100 casualties remains a high bar IMO
Increasing chance for the potential of rapid escalation, (no comment on some of these sources credibility);
Reportedly, count is at three.

"Secretary of State Antony Blinken on Monday held separate calls with the leaders of Armenia and Azerbaijan, offering U.S. support for what he called a “historic opportunity” to achieve peace in the region.
No buildup currently to reach a high bar of 100 fatalities. About, or less than, 1%.
it’s going on right now and has been for three weeks
Time
As of now my estimate stemmed from a general impression that the war will spread. I'm unsure this will be the case before October.
Passage of time
Hi all,
no update. No significant tension since the Russian invasion.

Up a bit. I still think this is unlikely given the question's short time frame, but Azerbaijan is in a better position militarily and politically as Europe now has a greater dependency on its liquified natural gas as it aims to reduce its dependency on Russia's gas.
1 month since my previous forecast, with 4.5 months left

I think its a little higher than @CesarDeOro credits, but not much. The key factor is "100 or more deaths." The conflict has flared up semi-regularly since the 1990s; as recently as this year border clashes resulted in thirty deaths (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021%E2%80%932022_Armenia%E2%80%93Azerbaijan_border_crisis). I think the relevant factors are a) Azerbaijan, based on its recent track record, feels it has military superiority. b) Russia's ability to keep the peace is limited by its commitments elsewhere c) Armenia's own internal political fallout from the last war is still ongoing; while I don't see revanchist Armenians attacking Azerbaijan, it seems like another reason for Azerbaijan to strike while the iron is hot. For all these reasons, I think there is a good chance of another conflict, possibly centered around Nakhchivan

I believe that Russia won't be able to achieve its goals in Ukraine (65% probability), potentially triggering a massive political crisis. Azerbaijan made a move before that, I am certain that in such case it will do it for sure (90%).
Passage of time -> down from 10 to 9
The war in Ukraine has a good chance of igniting more violence in all former Soviet republics.

Further issues initiated by armed insurrections due to russian war, but peace treaties are under way https://www.noticiasdealava.eus/actualidad/mundo/2022/04/11/armenia-azerbaiyan-preparan-acuerdo-paz/1180004.html

While Armenia and Azerbaijan have recently battled in NK, and both contest the territory, both countries have powerful backers: Azerbaijan had Turkey and Armenia was supported by the Russian Federation. However, the recent reignition of the conflict was a very clear victory for Azerbaijan, who reconquered most of the contested territories and agreed to a peace deal granting it access to several exclaves and recuperation of occupied Az territory (not contest by Armenia juridically but nonetheless occupied since the first war). The political victory was significant for Baku, who could have interest in reigniting and terminating the war, given the current bogging down of Russian forces in Ukraine as a potential opportunity to seize further territories against its Armenian counterpart. Armenia on the other hand, has seen protesters cultivating a revanchist discourse (https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/defence/scarred-by-war-armenian-veterans-look-warily-to-the-future/articleshow/81376857.cms?from=mdr) and could be tempted to reignite the conflict as a means to distract its population, albeit in a very isolated manner. As such, tensions remain high in the region, but the current power imbalance does not favour escalation.

I tend to veer towards saying that this is rather unlikely: in inter-state rivalries, the "loser" tends to create the counterattack. Armenia lost the NK region a few years back, but is, as of yet, not powerful enough to meaningfully retake territory from the Azerbaijanis. Azerbaijan has likely continued to make use of Turkish drones and other hardware, not to mention dug in in the mountains. Armenia's main ally, Russia, has its hands tied to be able to counterbalance Turkey in the region.
My previous rationale mostly stands but if 2 of the last 10 years had 100 fatalities then this should be a base rate of more like 10% for a 6 month period

It looks like there is some form of clash between Armenia and Azerbaijan resulting in fatalities the majority of years of the last decade, at least two of which resulted in 100 fatalities. Plus Azerbaijan is clearly saber rattling and is seeing an opportunity with Russia occupied. Possible that 25% is a little too high since the question is only 6 months, but it would be very easy to see it happening

From article above: Radio Free Europe "Advancing Azerbaijani armed forces appeared behind the Russian peacekeepers’ backs.” The article above describes the 2020, six week war that ends with 6,500 dead and Armenia ceding territories to Azerbaijan along with a Russian brokered cease fire enforced by Russian peacekeepers.

I don't know much about this and haven't done any research, so don't follow me too much. However, basic premise is that a conflict with over 100 fatalities is already a really serious conflict, rather than a simmering thing, and that just feels unlikely.
